==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|へい|ばん|かた|k3=がた|r=y}}

===Etymology===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=へいばんがた|平板|tr1=[[heiban]]|t1=[[flat]]; [[monotone]]|型|tr2=[[gata]]|t2=[[type]]}}

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|へいばんがた|acc=h}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|へいばん-がた}}

# {{lb|ja|phonetics|sort=へいばんがた}} [[monotone]] [[type]]:
#: The most common pitch accent pattern in “standard” Japanese or {{m|ja|標準語|tr=hyōjungo}} as used in the mass-media, where no syllable is accented: the first syllable has low pitch and all subsequent syllables have higher, gradually lowering pitch.

====Synonyms====
* {{ja-r|平板式|へいばん-しき}}

====Usage notes====
All accent patterns in Japanese may be described as either {{ja-l|平板式||heiban-shiki}} or {{ja-l|起伏式||kifuku-shiki}}. While {{lang|ja|起伏式}} is further divided into {{ja-l|頭高型||atamadaka-gata}}, {{ja-l|中高型||nakadaka-gata}}, and {{ja-l|尾高型||odaka-gata}}, there are no subcategories to {{lang|ja|平板式}}. When contrasting with {{lang|ja|頭高型}}, {{lang|ja|中高型}}, or {{lang|ja|尾高型}}, it is customary to use the word {{lang|ja|平板型}} to avoid the inconsistency of comparing {{ja-l|型||-gata}} with {{ja-l|式||-shiki}}.
